awd_titl_txt: Quantitative analysis of local calcium release across cell types
awd_abstract_narration:
The release of calcium inside cells is critically important for such functions as muscle contraction (including heartbeat) and egg (oocyte) maturation. Calcium release signals are initiated by local events inside cells known as "sparks" or "puffs" and these lead to the release of calcium throughout the cell. This project will test whether the mechanisms that control calcium sparks and puffs are involved respectively in the physiological process of cell-wide calcium release in oocytes and the cell-wide release of calcium in heart cells which, if not tightly controlled, can lead to problems with uncoordinated contractions of heart muscle (irregular heart beat.) Undergraduate students from the City University of New York will be engaged with this research project, learning concepts of both cell biology and the mathematical modeling of biological processes. The studies carried out by undergraduates will be included in a "Teaching Resource" publication that will make widely available teaching materials to which undergraduates have made major contributions. 

The hypothesis to be tested is that mechanisms of puff termination will encourage physiological, cell-wide Ca2+ release in oocytes whereas spark termination mechanisms will suppress pathological cell-wide Ca2+ release in cardiac myocytes. In this project, simulations will be carried out to evaluate how the mechanisms of activation and termination of sparks and puffs influence event variability within release sites and between sites. The relationships between Ca2+ sparks, Ca2+ puffs, and the transition from local events to cell-wide Ca2+ waves will also be simulated, and modeling predictions will be tested experimentally (using Xenopus oocytes and rat cardiac myocytes)  by measuring variability in Ca2+ sparks,variability in Ca2+ puffs, and how this influences the spark/puff to Ca2+ wave transition.

por.por_cntn:
NATIONAL SCIENCE FOUNDATION

MCB 1615677  

Eric A. Sobie, Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai

Project Outcomes Report

 

NSF project MCB 161577 aimed to examine the regulation of calcium across different cell types. Calcium is important in many biological processes, from muscle contraction to fertilization of mammalian eggs. The concentration of calcium within cells usually starts at a very low level, then a dramatic increase in concentration signals the cell to initiate an important process, such as muscle contraction. However, the processes that regulate calcium concentration differ dramatically between cell types, and the reason for divergent forms of regulation is not known. In this project we used a combination of mathematical modeling and experimental measurements to explore the idea that alternative forms of regulation evolved to allow calcium to play different functional roles across a variety of cell types.

This project made significant progress and had many positive outcomes, in terms of both the intellectual merit and the broader impacts of the work. These included:

  • New predictions about how divergent forms of regulation could either promote spontaneous increases in calcium, in cells where this is desirable, or suppress these increases, in cells where these events are detrimental (Figure 1).
  • A novel mathematical model of calcium regulation in heart cells that includes both microscopic structural features and the effects of randomness. This model, published recently, will be a tremendous resource for researchers in the field examining how mis-regulation of calcium may contribute to disease (Figure 2).
  • New laboratory exercises that were used to introduce undergraduate summer researchers to both the modeling and experimental methods used in the project. We are currently writing descriptions of these laboratory exercises that we plan to publish as an educational tool, to increase the scope and the broader impacts of the research.

Overall, this project provided novel insight into how calcium functions across a wide range of cell types. The tools and methods we developed can be applied to multiple disciplines, from cardiology, to neuroscience, to evolutionary biology.  

 

 


Last Modified: 11/30/2023
Modified by: Eric Sobie
